bibl.title: Report: The Conduct of Lena A. Warner, by Jefferson Randolph Kean, April 17, 1902

div1.p: Kean writes about Lena A. Warner's refusal to care for an officer's wife.

div1.head: Report: The Conduct of Lena A. Warner, by Jefferson Randolph Kean, April 17, 1902
div1.opener:
unclear
3rd Endorsement.
HEADQUARTERS DEPARTMENT OF CUBA.
DEPARTMENT OF CHARITIES.
HAVANA: APR. 17, 1902.
div1.p:
Respectfully returned to the
Chief Surgeon, Department of
Cuba.

With regard to the conversa-
tion between Mrs. Lena Warner
and her Commanding Officer on
March 19, 1902, I have no know-
ledge. My only interview with
her on the subject of doing out-
side duty was shortly after I
became Post Surgeon in March,
1901, when I asked her to go
over and spend the night with
the wife of an Officer who was
ill and alone, the officer being
absent on duty. This request
was refused. Next day I called
together the trained nurses and
told them that thereafter when
emergencies arose in officers'
families, I would expect them
to share the responsability which
I, as the Medical Officer, had
in the care of these cases, and
attend them if necessary; that
if any nurse objected to this I
might ask for her transfer to
another post where the Post Sur-
geon would be less exacting. At
this interview all the nurses
expressed a willingness to go
and attend cases in the service
where I deemed emergency to ex-
ist. My reason for taking this
stand was that in case of the oc-
currence of an epedemic disease
among the female members of an
Original not passed through records.
32
officer's or soldier's family, it
would be manifestly my duty as
Post Surgeon to see that the case
had proper attention and it would
also be manifestly impossible to
have the case attended to by the
enlisted men of the Hospital Corps
I exercised this authority in one
instance thereafter, sending a
nurse to care for a child sick in
with diptheria in the family of
a soldier, the mother being at
the time on the eve of confine-
ment. This action was taken by
order of the Chief Surgeon, but
I would have been perfectly wil-
ling to have assumed the responsi-
bility therefor.

Under my observation, Mrs.
Warner was not very desirous either
to do hard work or incur any un-
necessary risks. I do not recall
an occasion upon which her ser-
vices for outside work were de-
sired when it was possible to
secure another nurse at any price.

Major & Surgeon, U.S.A.
Supt. Department of Charities. --ooOOoo--

div1.p:
Lena A. Warner. Nurse.
Memphis Tenn. 4.9.1902.

Having learned that her ser-
vices have been reported unsatis
factorely by the Chief Surgeon
at Columbia Barracks makes a
statement in re to her services
announcing that services were
asked of her in violation
of A.N. Regulations. Requests tha
this paper be filed with her
record.
